The FI Formula Explained

The Financial Independence formula is simple, but powerful: Your FI Number = Annual Expenses × 25. This comes from the 4% Rule—withdraw 4% of your portfolio annually, and it should last 30+ years.

Where Does This Come From?

The Trinity Study found that a 4% withdrawal rate historically sustained retirement for 30 years in most scenarios. To calculate: if you spend $40,000/year, your FI target is $1,000,000.

The Variables That Matter

  • Expenses: Lower expenses mean a smaller FI number.
  • Income: Higher savings rate accelerates FI more than a big salary alone.
  • Returns: Investment growth assumptions (typically 5–7% real return).

Time to FI and Savings Rate

The most important factor? Your savings rate. A 50% savings rate can get you to FI in 15 years, even with modest returns.

Beyond the Math

FI isn’t just math—it’s psychology. Don’t sacrifice happiness or purpose for speed. Money is a tool, not the end goal.
